liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In a tweet, the Israel Defense Forces say they have started "striking Hezbollah terrorist targets in Lebanon". Israel earlier ordered the evacuation of 28 villages in a 2-kilometre-deep zone near its northern border with Lebanon. Lebanon's Hezbollah movement said it had targeted five Israeli positions. Clashes in the past week have been the deadliest in the Lebanon border area since a 2006 war between Israel and Hezbollah, which is an ally of Iran. With AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Israel striking Hezbollah targets in Lebanon: IDF

children.content: In a tweet, the Israel Defense Forces say they have started "striking Hezbollah terrorist targets in Lebanon".
Israel earlier ordered the evacuation of 28 villages in a 2-kilometre-deep zone near its northern border with Lebanon.
Lebanon's Hezbollah movement said it had targeted five Israeli positions.
Clashes in the past week have been the deadliest in the Lebanon border area since a 2006 war between Israel and Hezbollah, which is an ally of Iran.
With AP

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has spoken in his country's parliament about the ongoing war. He says Israel's goal remains "a crushing victory over Hamas, toppling its regime and removing its threat to the State of Israel once and for all". "Determination is required because victory will take time. There will be difficult moments. There will be pitfalls. Sacrifice will be necessary." He also issued a warning to Iran and Hezbollah, who have said they would get involved if Israeli troops march into Gaza. "Do not test us in the north. Do not repeat your previous mistake because the price you will pay will be much worse," Mr Netanyahu said. "President Biden told you in English: 'Don't do it.' I tell you in Hebrew: Be careful. "We have gone to war. We will win. We will not stop until victory."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Netanyahu warns Iran not to get involved while speaking to Israeli parliament

props.alt: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu speaks to parliament.

children.content: (Twitter: @IsraeliPM)
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has spoken in his country's parliament about the ongoing war.
He says Israel's goal remains "a crushing victory over Hamas, toppling its regime and removing its threat to the State of Israel once and for all".
"Determination is required because victory will take time. There will be difficult moments. There will be pitfalls. Sacrifice will be necessary."
He also issued a warning to Iran and Hezbollah, who have said they would get involved if Israeli troops march into Gaza.
"Do not test us in the north. Do not repeat your previous mistake because the price you will pay will be much worse," Mr Netanyahu said.
"President Biden told you in English: 'Don't do it.' I tell you in Hebrew: Be careful.
"We have gone to war. We will win. We will not stop until victory."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A top Hamas leader said on Monday the group "has what it needs" to free all Palestinians in Israel's jails, indicating the militant group may try to use Israelis it kidnapped as bargaining chips to secure the release of prisoners. Soon after Hamas official Khaled Meshaal made the remarks on the captives — which include Israelis and non-Israelis taken hostage by Hamas on October 7 — the group's armed wing separately said the non-Israelis were "guests" who would be released "when circumstances allow". Israel's military says the group is holding 199 hostages in Gaza. Hamas says it has between 200 and 250. Hamas, which like other factions has long called for the release of the roughly 6,000 Palestinians in Israeli prisons, "has what it needs to empty the prisons of all prisoners," Meshaal, a former Hamas chief who now heads its diaspora office in Doha, told AlAraby TV. Israel, which has bombarded Gaza with strikes that have killed hundreds of Palestinians, has said it would act to free the hostages while eliminating Hamas. The captives are believed to include nationals of countries including Thailand and Germany. Other countries have reported their citizens as missing. Israelis with dual nationality in countries including the US are also believed to have been kidnapped. In a video message, the spokesman of Hamas' armed wing, Abu Obeida, said Hamas has "a group of detainees of different nationalities, these are our guests and we seek to protect them". He added: "We will release detainees of different nationalities when circumstances on the ground allow." He did not elaborate. Another senior Hamas official, Moussa Abu Marzouk, said on Monday that "foreign prisoners cannot be released due to the continued Israeli bombing of the Gaza Strip". Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hamas seeks release of roughly 6,000 Palestinian prisoners, says it will free non-Israeli captives

children.content: A top Hamas leader said on Monday the group "has what it needs" to free all Palestinians in Israel's jails, indicating the militant group may try to use Israelis it kidnapped as bargaining chips to secure the release of prisoners.

Soon after Hamas official Khaled Meshaal made the remarks on the captives — which include Israelis and non-Israelis taken hostage by Hamas on October 7 — the group's armed wing separately said the non-Israelis were "guests" who would be released "when circumstances allow".
Israel's military says the group is holding 199 hostages in Gaza. Hamas says it has between 200 and 250.

Hamas, which like other factions has long called for the release of the roughly 6,000 Palestinians in Israeli prisons, "has what it needs to empty the prisons of all prisoners," Meshaal, a former Hamas chief who now heads its diaspora office in Doha, told AlAraby TV.
Israel, which has bombarded Gaza with strikes that have killed hundreds of Palestinians, has said it would act to free the hostages while eliminating Hamas.

The captives are believed to include nationals of countries including Thailand and Germany. Other countries have reported their citizens as missing. Israelis with dual nationality in countries including the US are also believed to have been kidnapped.
In a video message, the spokesman of Hamas' armed wing, Abu Obeida, said Hamas has "a group of detainees of different nationalities, these are our guests and we seek to protect them".
He added: "We will release detainees of different nationalities when circumstances on the ground allow." He did not elaborate.
Another senior Hamas official, Moussa Abu Marzouk, said on Monday that "foreign prisoners cannot be released due to the continued Israeli bombing of the Gaza Strip".
Reuters

items.synopsis: Follow live as we bring you the latest updates from the Voice referendum fallout, for Tuesday October 17.

title.children: Linda Burney says government will consider its next move following referendum defeat

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's former ambassador to the United States John McCarthy has told ABC News the rejection of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament will be viewed negatively in the Asia-Pacific region. Sixty per cent of Australians voted against enshrining a Voice in the Constitution at the weekend. Mr McCarthy says the 'No' result will be a concern for Australia's Pacific neighbours. "People don't look at all the intricacies of the No vote but what they do see is a rejection of Indigenous aspirations in Australia by a majority of people in Australia, so it's as stark as that and that will have an adverse impact in the way we are regarded more generally I think, globally."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former US ambassador says Voice referendum rejection will be a concern for the Asia-Pacific region

children.content: Australia's former ambassador to the United States
John
McCarthy
has told ABC News the rejection of the Indigenous Voice to Parliament will be viewed negatively in the Asia-Pacific region.
Sixty per cent of Australians voted against enshrining a Voice in the Constitution at the weekend.
Mr McCarthy says the 'No' result will be a concern for Australia's Pacific neighbours.

"People don't look at all the intricacies of the No vote but what they do see is a rejection of Indigenous aspirations in Australia by a majority of people in Australia, so it's as stark as that and that will have an adverse impact in the way we are regarded more generally I think, globally."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Assistant Minister for Indigenous Australians, Malarndirri McCarthy says many are "deeply disappointed in their fellow Australians" after the country voted against a Voice to Parliament. When asked by ABC's RN Breakfast if Australia "got it right" in terms of the outcome of the referendum, Ms McCarthy says she finds it "deeply disappointing" Australians don't want a Voice to Parliament. "It's not right as a First Nations person to have to keep explaining why your history is important in this country and why we have been here for over 65,000 years." Ms McCarthy says there is still urgency to address issues for First Nations people, but there needs to be some time to regroup and recover first. "People are feeling absolutely hurt right now. Deeply disappointed in their fellow Australians. "They need time to mourn as the First Nations have said in terms of their silence this week." Listen to the full interview here.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Assistant Minister for Indigenous Australians says many are 'deeply disappointed'

featuredLink.title: Malarndirri McCarthy on the Voice: 'I think we could have been better' - ABC listen

children.content: Assistant Minister for Indigenous Australians, Malarndirri McCarthy says many are "deeply disappointed in their fellow Australians" after the country voted against a Voice to Parliament.

When asked by ABC's RN Breakfast if Australia "got it right" in terms of the outcome of the referendum, Ms McCarthy says she finds it "deeply disappointing" Australians don't want a Voice to Parliament.
"It's not right as a First Nations person to have to keep explaining why your history is important in this country and why we have been here for over 65,000 years."
Ms McCarthy says there is still urgency to address issues for First Nations people, but there needs to be some time to regroup and recover first.
"People are feeling absolutely hurt right now. Deeply disappointed in their fellow Australians.
"They need time to mourn as the First Nations have said in terms of their silence this week."
Listen to the full interview here.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Indigenous Australians Minister Linda Burney says the government will now consider its next move. Just 40 per cent of Australians backed the proposal, with the voice failing to win a majority in any state. Ms Burney says the high Indigenous vote for the Voice was a positive sign. "That says to me that Indigenous Australians wanted this," she told the ABC's 7.30 program on Monday. "What the government will do is let the dust settle and we will be undertaking a process of finding out where people want to move next." Watch the full interview below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Indigenous Australians Minister says govt is considering its next move

children.content: Indigenous Australians Minister
Linda Burney
says the government will now consider its next move.
Just 40 per cent of Australians backed the proposal, with the voice failing to win a majority in any state.
Ms Burney says the high Indigenous vote for the Voice was a positive sign.
"That says to me that Indigenous Australians wanted this," she told the ABC's
7.30 program
on Monday.
"What the government will do is let the dust settle and we will be undertaking a process of finding out where people want to move next."
Watch the
full interview below.

mediaThumbnail.caption: With the referendum defeated, how do we now address Indigenous disadvantage?

children.content: Laura Tingle

document.caption:
The defeat of the Voice to Parliament referendum on the weekend has left its supporters grieving, and prompted a debate about what the result says about Australia as a country. It also raises the question of how we now address Indigenous disadvantage.

Chief political correspondent Laura Tingle reports.

children.content: The defeat of the Voice to Parliament referendum on the weekend has left its supporters grieving, and prompted a debate about what the result says about Australia as a country. It also raises the question of how we now address Indigenous disadvantage.

title.children: Port Adelaide makes draft threat as AFL trade period reaches crucial penultimate day

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: There is a heap on the plate still of Port Adelaide and list bost Chris Davies. At least four deals are still up in the air, and the Power aren't flinching on either of them just yet. Davies was on Trade Radio this morning, here's an upshot of what he had to say: Port Adelaide will walk Brandon Zerk-Thatcher and Esava Ratugolea to the draft if deals can't be done with Essendon and Geelong Port are reluctant to directly swap Zerk-Thatcher for Xavier Duursma Ivan Soldo has told Port he wants to join them, and Davies says the club will endeavour to make that happen — though he concedes it will be tough as Soldo is under contract at Richmond Davies believes Jordon Sweet will get to Port Adelaide by tomorrow night Davies seemed optimistic all of these deals could be done, but as you can see there is a fair bit on for our friends from Alberton.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Port Adelaide's busy two days

children.content: (Getty Images)
There is a heap on the plate still of Port Adelaide and list bost Chris Davies. At least four deals are still up in the air, and the Power aren't flinching on either of them just yet.
Davies was on Trade Radio this morning, here's an upshot of what he had to say:
Port Adelaide will walk Brandon Zerk-Thatcher and Esava Ratugolea to the draft if deals can't be done with Essendon and Geelong
Port are reluctant to directly swap Zerk-Thatcher for Xavier Duursma
Ivan Soldo has told Port he wants to join them, and Davies says the club will endeavour to make that happen — though he concedes it will be tough as Soldo is under contract at Richmond
Davies believes Jordon Sweet will get to Port Adelaide by tomorrow night
Davies seemed optimistic all of these deals could be done, but as you can see there is a fair bit on for our friends from Alberton.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Financial markets have been on a wild ride for much of this year and the volatility has only increased in recent weeks. Buffeted by geopolitical forces on three fronts — Russia, China and now the Middle East — the immediate fallout from these regional conflicts has sent short term shock waves through commodity markets. Longer term, they have upended trading patterns and drawn the curtain on almost three decades of global trade liberalisation, ushering in a new Cold War that's threatening to turn hot. On its own, that's enough to slow growth and jack up prices. Read more from business editor Ian Verrender.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Analysis: Why global financial markets are walking a tightrope

featuredLink.title: Why global financial markets are walking a tightrope

children.content: Financial markets have been on a wild ride for much of this year and the volatility has only increased in recent weeks.
Buffeted by geopolitical forces on three fronts —
Russia, China and now the Middle East —
the immediate fallout from these regional conflicts has sent short term shock waves through commodity markets.

Longer term, they have upended trading patterns and drawn the curtain on almost three decades of global trade liberalisation, ushering in a new Cold War that's threatening to turn hot. On its own, that's enough to slow growth and jack up prices.
Read more from
business editor Ian Verrender.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The competition between mortgage lenders to get your business could soon be heating up again, analysts say. The nation's biggest bank has lost market share in the residential lending space (including owner-occupier and investor home loans) for the first time in more than five years. Analysts believe the Commonwealth Bank will not allow its market share to shrink much further. Read more from business reporter Emily Stewart.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mortgage competition between the banks could heat up again

featuredLink.title: Could you be getting a better deal on your home loan interest rate?

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US stocks ended sharply higher on Monday as investors were optimistic about the start of earnings season, with transportation shares advancing. Investors were monitoring the Israel-Gaza war, but appeared to be taking more of a risk-on stance, with safe-haven gold prices down. Results from large banks Goldman Sachs, Bank of America, Morgan Stanley, pharmaceutical giant Johnson & Johnson, electric vehicle maker Tesla and video-streaming pioneer Netflix are due this week. Third-quarter earnings for S & P 500 companies are estimated to have increased 2.2 per cent year-over-year, according to LSEG data Friday. "At least for today (Monday), this is a market that sees a stronger earnings season, a stronger week in terms of earnings," said Quincy Krosby, chief global strategist, LPL Financial in Charlotte, North Carolina. At the same time, global leaders were trying to make sure that the Middle East conflict "remains contained," she said. The Dow Jones index rose 0.9 per cent, the S & P 500 gained 1.1 per cent and the Nasdaq Composite up 1.2 per cent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wall Street ends sharply higher

children.content: US stocks ended sharply higher on Monday as investors were optimistic about the start of earnings season, with transportation shares advancing.
Investors were monitoring the Israel-Gaza war, but appeared to be taking more of a risk-on stance, with safe-haven gold prices down.
Results from large banks Goldman Sachs, Bank of America, Morgan Stanley, pharmaceutical giant Johnson
Johnson, electric vehicle maker Tesla and video-streaming pioneer Netflix are due this week.
Third-quarter earnings for S
P 500 companies are estimated to have increased 2.2 per cent year-over-year, according to LSEG data Friday.

"At least for today (Monday), this is a market that sees a stronger earnings season, a stronger week in terms of earnings," said Quincy Krosby, chief global strategist, LPL Financial in Charlotte, North Carolina.
At the same time, global leaders were trying to make sure that the Middle East conflict "remains contained," she said.
The Dow Jones index rose 0.9 per cent, the S
P 500 gained 1.1 per cent and the Nasdaq Composite up 1.2 per cent.
